chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of pruritus vulvae
chapter.summary: Covers the management of pruritus vulvae both when an underlying cause has been established and when an underlying cause cannot be found.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth onwards (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage pruritus vulvae with a known cause?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• A comprehensive discussion of the management of specific causes of pruritus vulvae is beyond the scope of this topic. A brief discussion follows, with links to other relevant CKS topics.
  • Most women who present with pruritus vulvae have an identifiable cause which can be managed, including:
    • Dermatological conditions.
    • Infections and infestations.
    • Possible neoplasm.
    • Hormonal changes.
    • Gastrointestinal disease and urinary incontinence.
    • Systemic causes.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage dermatological conditions?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Manage the underlying dermatological cause of pruritus vulvae in primary care where appropriate.
    • Contact dermatitis
      • Identify and remove exposure to irritants (for example soaps and deodorants).
      • For mild itching, consider prescribing a mild potency topical corticosteroid ointment, such as hydrocortisone 1% for 7–10 days.
      • Stronger potency corticosteroids (such as betamethasone or clobetasol) may be considered if, symptoms are severe, if the skin is lichenified, or to break the itch-scratch-cycle. 
      • Recommend an emollient as a soap substitute. 
      • Treat co-existing infection with a combination corticosteroid/antifungal, or corticosteroid/antibacterial if required.
      • Consider referral to dermatology for skin patch testing if avoidance of irritants and topical corticosteroids have not improved the condition.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Dermatitis - contact.
    • Seborrhoeic dermatitis
      • Ketoconazole shampoo can be used as body wash for seborrhoeic dermatitis.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Seborrhoeic dermatitis.
    • Psoriasis
      • For management information, see the section on Treatment in the CKS topic on Psoriasis.
    • Lichen simplex
      • Identify and avoid precipitating factors.
      • Consider prescribing a potent topical corticosteroid ointment (such as betamethasone), for 1–2 weeks to break the itch-scratch cycle and bring the condition under control.
      • Consider prescribing a mildly anxiolytic antihistamine (for example hydroxyzine) for use at night.
      • Recommend an emollient as a soap substitute.
    • Lichen sclerosus and lichen planus
      • Refer to secondary care to confirm the diagnosis.
      • Once the diagnosis is confirmed in secondary care, very potent corticosteroids are usually initiated by a specialist. Repeated, intermittent courses of topical steroids may be required for longer-term management.
  • For more information on prescribing:
    • Topical corticosteroids: see the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes.
    • Emollients: see the section on Emollients in the CKS topic on Eczema - atopic.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV guideline UK national guideline on the management of vulval conditions [BASHH, 2014], the 2016 European guideline for the management of vulval conditions [van der Meijden, 2017], and expert opinion in a narrative review Recognition and management of vulvar dermatologic conditions: lichen sclerosus, Lichen planus, and lichen simplex chronicus [Thorstensen, 2012].

Preference for corticosteroid ointment over cream [van der Meijden, 2017]
  • Corticosteroid ointments are preferred to creams on the anogenital skin, as they have a reduced need for preservatives, which may cause secondary contact allergy.
  • Creams also have more water content than ointments and may sting when applied.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage infections or infestations?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For information on managing the underlying infection or infestation, see the CKS topics on:
    • Bacterial vaginosis.
    • Candida - female genital.
    • Herpes simplex - genital.
    • Pubic lice.
    • Scabies.
    • Threadworm.
    • Trichomoniasis.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a possible vulval neoplasm?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer urgently (within 2 weeks) all women with: 
    • An unexplained vulval lump, ulceration, or bleeding.  
      • Suspect vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) for any persistent area of abnormality that is thick, warty or ulcerated. 
    • An unexplained palpable mass in, or at the entrance to the vagina.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence guidance Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2015] and expert opinion in a narrative review Common vulval dermatoses [Drummond, 2011].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage hormonal changes which cause pruritus vulvae?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Manage pruritus vulvae appropriately, depending on the underlying cause:
    • Atrophic vaginitis — see the CKS topic on Menopause.
    • Pregnancy — see the CKS topic on Itch in pregnancy.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The evidence to support the management of hormonal changes is discussed within the relevant CKS topic.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage gastrointestinal disease or urinary incontinence which is causing pruritus vulvae?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Manage pruritus vulvae appropriately, depending on the underlying cause:
    • Faecal incontinence — manage faecal incontinence (for example regular toileting, use of barrier creams). Refer to a specialist if required. 
    • Poor perianal hygiene — provide advice on appropriate hygiene measures.
    • Urinary incontinence — for information on managing urinary incontinence, see the CKS topic on Incontinence - urinary, in women.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on expert opinion in a narrative review Recognition and management of vulvar dermatologic conditions: lichen sclerosus, lichen planus, and lichen simplex chronicus [Thorstensen, 2012], and what CKS considers to be good practice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a systemic cause of pruritus vulvae?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Manage the underlying cause:
    • Anaemia (iron deficiency) —  see the CKS topic on Anaemia - iron deficiency.
    • Anaemia (vitamin B12 and folate deficiency) — see the CKS topic on Anaemia - B12 and folate deficiency. 
    • Diabetes mellitus — see the CKS topics on Diabetes - type 1 and Diabetes - type 2.
    • Hepatic disease — see the CKS topics on Gallstones, Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, and Jaundice in adults. 
    • Hyperthyroidism — see the CKS topic on Hyperthyroidism.
    • Hypothyroidism — see the CKS topic on Hypothyroidism.
    • End-stage renal disease — see the CKS topic on Chronic kidney disease.
    • Suspected lymphoma — consider a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks).
    • Psychological problems — consider referral to a psychiatrist, if appropriate. See the CKS topics on Depression, Generalized anxiety disorder and Insomnia.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) guideline Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2015], the British Medical Journal (BMJ) Best Practice guide Assessment of pruritus [BMJ, 2017], and what CKS consider good clinical practice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage pruritus vulvae with an unknown cause?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The aim of treatment is to provide symptomatic relief, reduce inflammation, restore the skin barrier and prevent and/or treat secondary infection. 

  • Offer symptomatic treatment with an emollient and a mildly anxiolytic antihistamine (such as hydroxyzine).
  • Consider prescribing a short trial (1-2 weeks) of low potency topical corticosteroids (hydrocortisone 1% ointment).
  • Consider prescribing a combination corticosteroid/antifungal, or corticosteroid/antibacterial if a co-existing infection is suspected.
  • If symptoms persist despite treatment with an emollient, an antihistamine, and a trial of low potency topical corticosteroids, refer for further investigation to a dermatologist, gynaecologist, or vulval clinic depending on local referral pathways. 
  • Advise the woman to continue using an emollient and an antihistamine while awaiting specialist appointment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
CKS found no guidelines on managing pruritus vulvae where no underlying cause has been identified. These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline on the management of vulval conditions [BASHH, 2014], and expert opinion in the (BASHH) a narrative review Vulvar dermatoses: a practical approach to evaluation and management [Stewart, 2012], and what CKS considers good clinical practice. 

  • CKS considers that in the absence of a known cause, a general treatment approach should be considered.
    • A general treatment approach, including restoring the skin barrier, reducing inflammation, symptomatic relief, and preventing and treating secondary infection has the potential to address vulvar symptoms caused by eczematous dermatitis, lichen simplex chronicus, and allergic or irritant contact dermatitis [Stewart, 2012].
    • This approach also may significantly improve symptoms of lichen sclerosus, lichen planus, and psoriasis [Stewart, 2012].
  • Opinion from CKS expert reviewers was divided regarding the use of low potency topical corticosteroids in women who have pruritus vulvae with an unknown cause.
  • However, CKS recommends that treatment may be considered on the basis that some women may benefit, and a short trial of low potency corticosteroids is unlikely to cause harm.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What symptomatic treatment should I offer a woman with pruritus vulvae?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For all women with pruritus vulvae, consider prescribing:
    • An emollient — advise the woman to apply the emollient directly to the vulval area regularly as well as using it as a soap substitute.
      • When used regularly (even when there are no symptoms), an emollient protects the skin against local irritants (for example, urine or menstrual blood) and may help to prevent flare-ups.
      • For more information on prescribing emollients, see the section on Emollients in the CKS topic on Eczema - atopic.
    • A mildly anxiolytic antihistamine at night, such as hydroxyzine to reduce nocturnal itching.
    • Do not prescribe hydroxyzine if the person has a prolonged QT interval or risk factors for QT interval prolongation. For more information, see the section on prescribing information in the CKS topic on Itch - widespread.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline on the management of vulval conditions [BASHH, 2014], the 2016 European guideline for the management of vulval conditions [van der Meijden, 2017], and expert opinion in narrative reviews Recognition and management of vulvar dermatologic conditions: lichen sclerosus, lichen planus, and lichen simplex chronicus [Thorstensen, 2012] and Vulvar dermatoses: a practical approach to evaluation and management [Stewart, 2012]. 

  • The recommendation not to prescribe hydroxyzine if the person has a prolonged QT interval, or risk factors for QT interval prolongation, is based on a Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) drug safety update [MHRA, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What self-care advice should I give to women with pruritus vulvae?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the woman:
    • To shower rather than bath, and to clean the vulval area (a maximum of once a day) with an emollient as a soap substitute — over cleaning may aggravate vulval symptoms. Once the vulval area is clean, gently dab the vulval area dry with a soft towel or use a hairdryer on a cool setting held well away from the skin.
  • Advise women with pruritus vulvae to avoid:
    • Washing with water only, or with soap, as these cause dry skin and make itching worse.
    • Contact of the vulval skin with:
      • Shampoo.
      • Bubble bath.
      • Over-the-counter preparations used on the vulva.
      • Wet wipes (feminine or baby).
      • Perfumed sanitary towels and panty liners.
      • Sponges or flannels — these may irritate the skin.
      • Antiseptics.
    • Tight-fitting garments or synthetic clothes, for example nylon underwear, as these may irritate the vulval area.
    • Fabric conditioner or biological washing powder when washing underwear.
    • Use of spermicidally-lubricated condoms.
    • Coloured toilet paper.
    • Wearing nail varnish on fingernails if they are scratching.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline on the management of vulval conditions [BASHH, 2014], the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of vulval carcinoma [RCOG, 2014], the 2016 European guideline for the management of vulval conditions [van der Meijden, 2017], expert opinion in narrative reviews Overview of vulvar pruritus through the life cycle [Bohl, 2005], and Itchy vulva [DNNZ, 2016a], and patient information leaflets Care of vulval skin [BAD, 2016], and Skin conditions of the vulva [RCOG, 2013].

Self examination
  • The Vulval Pain Society recommends vulval self examination, however there is no evidence to show that this is beneficial [RCOG, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a woman with pruritus vulvae?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Referral to a dermatologist or gynaecologist with expertise in managing vulval disease is indicated if:
    • The cause of the pruritus vulvae is unclear and symptoms persist.
      • The urgency of the referral will depend on the nature of the symptoms and degree of concern (if any) about cancer.
    • The cause is known, but symptoms persist despite primary care management:
      • For example, some women with contact dermatitis may require referral to try and identify the irritant or allergen. If allergic contact dermatitis is suspected, then patch test investigations may be initiated.
    • A premalignant condition, such as vulval intraepithelial neoplasia, lichen sclerosus, or lichen planus, is suspected.
  • Urgent referral (within 2 weeks) is indicated if:
    • Vulval carcinoma is suspected (for example if the woman has an unexplained vulval lump or ulcer).
    • Lymphoma is suspected. 
  • Also consider referral to the appropriate specialist if the underlying cause of pruritus vulvae is systemic disease.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline on the management of vulval conditions [BASHH, 2014], the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) guideline Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2015] and the 2016 European guideline for the management of vulval conditions [van der Meijden, 2017].
